It sounds like all you needed was to register a TestListener so that, for e=
ach test, you could collect its name. What you do with those names afterwar=
d is totally up to the individual.

Writing the TestListener is nothing. At=
taching the TestListener to the TestRunner may take some work. I've never a=
ctually done it. I would have to look at the code.

I suppose you could hav=
e written your own TestRunner that instantiates the text runner, adds the l=
istener, asks the text runner to run the tests, then processes the results =
from your listener. Is this what you did? If not, then what did you do?

Th=
anks.

>So said Katie Gerg on 4/15/2003 --------------------
>I'm embarrass=
ed to post it because I'm really serious when I say I hacked
>it.  I have t=
o get a suite of automated tests done by the end of this week
>so I did it =
without completely understanding junit but I knew what I wanted
>to get out=
 of it.  The tests I need to run are highly specialized (they're
>the same =
with different inputs).
>
>I wanted a list of test cases so I know what tes=
t cases I've run against a
>build (hey I'm a qa person, I have to know what=
's in there not only what
>failed - esp. from a test coverage perspective).=
  I also wanted it in a
>format anyone could easily view, so I store the te=
st results in a vector
>that I dump out in an html format at the end (the l=
ocation is hardcoded for
>now but it'll eventually come from a property fil=
e).
>
>Anyway, I confronted the same issue you had with the listener so I m=
ade my
>own testresult object that the testcase class initializes and the l=
istener
>grabs it from it.
>
>I'll send it to you but I don't think it fits=
 into the junit way of
>thinking.
>
>
>
